clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
funFact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
funFact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
funFact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: Home to a famous clock tower that isn’t actually called Big Ben.
You can take a ride on the iconic red double-decker buses.
funFact: Big Ben actually refers to the bell inside the tower, not the tower itself!
London has over 170 museums, including the British Museum, which is free to visit.
trivia: The London Underground is the oldest subway system in the world.
There are more than 8 million trees in London, making it one of the greenest cities in the world.

clues: This city is home to a famous opera house with a sail-like design.
You can climb one of the world's most famous bridges here.
funFact: Sydney’s Harbour Bridge is the largest steel arch bridge in the world.
The Sydney Opera House took 14 years to complete and was originally estimated to cost $7 million but ended up costing $102 million!
trivia: Sydney has over 100 beaches, including the famous Bondi Beach.
Kangaroos outnumber humans in Australia by nearly 2:1!

clues: This city is home to the Colosseum, an ancient amphitheater.
Inside this city, there is an entirely different country!
funFact: Vatican City, the smallest country in the world, is located entirely within Rome.
Rome has more fountains than any other city in the world.
trivia: Ancient Romans used to wash their clothes in urine because of its ammonia content.
The city’s nickname is 'The Eternal City' because of its long and continuous history.

clues: This city is home to the tallest building in the world.
You can go skiing indoors even though it's in the desert!
funFact: The Burj Khalifa stands at a height of 828 meters, making it the tallest structure ever built.
Dubai has the world’s largest shopping mall, with over 1,200 stores.
trivia: Gold vending machines exist in Dubai, where you can buy gold bars like snacks!
There are no personal income taxes in Dubai.

clues: Home to a giant statue of Christ overlooking the city.
Famous for its carnival, samba music, and stunning beaches.
funFact: The iconic Christ the Redeemer statue was completed in 1931 and stands 30 meters tall.
Rio’s Copacabana Beach was named after a Bolivian town.
trivia: Rio de Janeiro means ‘River of January’ in Portuguese.
The city was the capital of Portugal from 1808 to 1821, making it the only European capital outside of Europe.

clues: This city was once divided by a wall for nearly 30 years.
Home to the Brandenburg Gate, a symbol of European unity.
funFact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice—around 1,700 in total!
The Berlin Wall fell in 1989, leading to German reunification.
trivia: Berlin has the largest Turkish population outside of Turkey.
Berlin’s Museum Island has five world-famous museums.

clues: This city is the only one in the world that sits on two continents.
Famous for its massive covered marketplace with over 4,000 shops.
funFact: The Grand Bazaar in Istanbul is one of the oldest and largest markets in the world.
Hagia Sophia has served as a church, mosque, and museum over the centuries.
trivia: Istanbul was formerly known as Constantinople.
Tulips, often associated with the Netherlands, actually originated in Turkey.

clues: Home to the famous Red Square and colorful onion-domed cathedral.
Its subway system is known for its palatial stations.
funFact: Moscow's metro stations are often called 'underground palaces' due to their grandeur.
The Kremlin has been the seat of Russian power for centuries.
trivia: Moscow is the northernmost and coldest megacity in the world.
The city has more billionaires than any other city in Europe.

clues: This city is famous for its unique architecture by Antoni Gaudí.
Home to one of the most successful football clubs in the world.
funFact: La Sagrada Familia has been under construction since 1882 and is still not finished.
Barcelona has 9 UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
trivia: The city has its own language, Catalan, in addition to Spanish.
Barcelona was the first city to win a RIBA Royal Gold Medal for its architecture.

clues: Home to the only remaining wonder of the ancient world.
The Nile River runs through this city.
funFact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years.
Cairo is known as 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' for its Islamic architecture.
trivia: Cairo's metro is one of only two in Africa.
The city was founded in 969 AD by the Fatimid dynasty.

clues: This city is known for its vibrant street life and ornate temples.
Home to the Grand Palace and Wat Arun.
funFact: Bangkok's full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world.
The city has over 400 temples.
trivia: Bangkok is known as 'Krung Thep' in Thai, which means 'City of Angels'.
The city is sinking at a rate of 2-3 cm per year.

clues: This city is known as the cradle of Western civilization.
Home to the ancient Acropolis and Parthenon.
funFact: Athens has been continuously inhabited for over 3,000 years.
The city is named after Athena, the Greek goddess of wisdom.
trivia: The first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens in 1896.
Athens has more theatrical stages than any other city in the world.

clues: This city is home to the Forbidden City and the Great Wall.
Known for its Peking duck and ancient palaces.
funFact: Beijing has seven UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
The city hosted the 2008 Summer Olympics.
trivia: Beijing means 'Northern Capital' in Chinese.
The Forbidden City is the largest ancient palatial structure in the world.

clues: This city is known for its stunning Table Mountain.
You can visit Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned.
funFact: Cape Town is one of the most multicultural cities in the world.
The city is home to the oldest working wine estate in South Africa.
trivia: Cape Town was originally developed as a supply station for Dutch ships.
The city has a unique floral kingdom with over 9,000 plant species.

clues: This city is built on the ruins of the ancient Aztec capital, Tenochtitlán.
Known for its vibrant culture and historic Zócalo square.
funFact: Mexico City sinks about 10 inches each year due to its foundation on a lakebed.
The city has the largest number of museums in the Americas.
trivia: Mexico City is the oldest capital city in the Americas.
The city has a floating garden system called 'chinampas' used since Aztec times.

clues: This city is known for its high-tech infrastructure and palaces.
Home to the bustling district of Gangnam.
funFact: Seoul has the fastest internet speeds in the world.
The city is surrounded by mountains, with Namsan Tower offering panoramic views.
trivia: Seoul means 'capital' in Korean.
The city has a population density twice that of New York City.

clues: This city is known for its historic trams and hilly landscape.
Home to the famous Belém Tower and pastel de nata.
funFact: Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in Western Europe, predating Rome by centuries.
The city was almost completely destroyed by an earthquake in 1755.
trivia: Lisbon has the longest bridge in Europe, the Vasco da Gama Bridge.
The city is built on seven hills, similar to Rome.

clues: This city is known as the 'Paris of South America'.
Famous for its tango music and dance.
funFact: Buenos Aires has the widest avenue in the world, Avenida 9 de Julio.
The city is home to one of the world's most beautiful bookstores, El Ateneo Grand Splendid.
trivia: Buenos Aires means 'Good Airs' in Spanish.
The city has more psychoanalysts per capita than any other city in the world.

clues: This city is home to the iconic CN Tower.
Known for its diverse population and vibrant arts scene.
funFact: Toronto is the most multicultural city in the world, with over 140 languages spoken.
The PATH is the largest underground shopping complex in the world.
trivia: Toronto means 'meeting place' in the Huron language.
The city hosts the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF), one of the largest publicly attended film festivals in the world.

clues: This city is the heart of the Bollywood film industry.
Home to the Gateway of India and Marine Drive.
funFact: Mumbai was originally a group of seven islands.
The city is home to the world's most expensive private residence, Antilia.
trivia: Mumbai was formerly known as Bombay.
The city has the largest number of millionaires and billionaires in India.

clues: This city is known for its classical music heritage and coffee houses.
Home to the Schönbrunn Palace and the Vienna State Opera.
funFact: Vienna has been ranked as the world's most livable city multiple times.
The city is famous for its Sachertorte, a chocolate cake with apricot jam.
trivia: Vienna was the home of famous composers like Mozart, Beethoven, and Strauss.
The city has over 100 museums.

clues: This city is known for its canals and cycling culture.
Home to the Anne Frank House and Van Gogh Museum.
funFact: Amsterdam has more bicycles than residents.
The city is built on 11 million wooden poles to support its buildings.
trivia: Amsterdam was originally a fishing village called Amstelredamme.
The city has over 1,500 bridges.

clues: This city is known for its skyline and bustling harbor.
Home to Victoria Peak and the Star Ferry.
funFact: Hong Kong has the most skyscrapers in the world.
The city has one of the world's highest per capita incomes.
trivia: Hong Kong means 'Fragrant Harbor' in Cantonese.
The city was a British colony until 1997.

clues: This city-state is known for its cleanliness and strict laws.
Home to Marina Bay Sands and Gardens by the Bay.
funFact: Singapore is one of the world's greenest cities, with over 50% green cover.
The city has a unique 'hawker' culture, with street food stalls offering a variety of cuisines.
trivia: Singapore is one of only three city-states in the world.
The city has four official languages: English, Malay, Mandarin, and Tamil.

clues: This city is known for its royal palace and vibrant nightlife.
Home to the Prado Museum and Retiro Park.
funFact: Madrid is the highest capital city in the European Union.
The city is famous for its tapas culture.
trivia: Madrid's official symbol is a bear climbing a strawberry tree.
The city has more bars per capita than any other city in Europe.

clues: This city is known for its iconic Petronas Twin Towers.
Home to Batu Caves and a vibrant street food scene.
funFact: Kuala Lumpur means 'muddy confluence' in Malay.
The city has a tropical rainforest within its boundaries, the Bukit Nanas Forest Reserve.
trivia: Kuala Lumpur is one of the fastest-growing metropolitan regions in Southeast Asia.
The city hosts the Formula One Malaysian Grand Prix.

clues: This city is famous for its Golden Gate Bridge.
Known for its steep hills and historic cable cars.
funFact: San Francisco was built on more than 50 hills.
The city is home to the largest and oldest Chinatown in North America.
trivia: San Francisco was originally called Yerba Buena.
The city experiences frequent fog, which locals call 'Karl the Fog'.
